text:
The most successful
efforts in this space

are efforts that are
really tightly integrated

with the core mission
of an organization.

This is less about sort
of men versus women,

and more about the
impact of stereotypes.

Bias training may not do as much as
we maybe hope or think it would do.

And so the question is, you know,
what can we do instead?

Even if we're maybe not able to
change people and de-bias people

in the short run,
we can still impact outcomes

by sort of having them operate through
different policies and procedures.

My experiences, both in the classroom
and in talking to organizations,

suggest that leading with data can be a
really helpful way of navigating this.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
I'm Katie Coffman.

I'm the Piramal Associate
Professor of Business Administration
at Harvard Business School.

And my research focuses on
gender and stereotyping,

and how those factors
impact outcomes at work.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Some of the research I and
others have done recently

has uncovered some really
interesting forces in terms of

understanding how people think about
novel and unexpected events in the future.

So we have a lot of
models that would say that

when we're thinking about future events,
we might use similar past events,

or similar past experiences to
sort of wrap our head around those

and come up with a model
for how to think about them.

And what our research
 has found is, you know,

what makes for a
similar past event

might be a lot broader than you
would have previously thought.

And so it turns out
that past experiences,

even those that may seem on
the surface fairly irrelevant

for thinking about something in the
future, actually have a pretty big impact

on how we anticipate and expect
different things in the future.

And the way this research started
was actually trying to understand

some of the heterogeneity
around beliefs about COVID.

And so we conducted a series of
surveys over several months,

trying to understand both what their
beliefs were about the severity of COVID,

and also how that connected to things
they've experienced in the past.

And what we found is that
people who had experienced

a health adversity in the past,
not something COVID related,

actually had sort of more pessimistic
beliefs about the severity of COVID,
even for other people.

Now that's obviously a
very specific example,

but in the years since we
started working on that research,

people have started to apply this type
of model to other scenarios as well.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

We are not sort of unbiased
thinkers about the future.

What I mean by that is the way that we
sort of see things and perceive things

is very much shaped by our own
background and experiences.

And so for that reason,
I think from a leader's perspective,

right, it's important to sort
of have some humility

about your own beliefs
in a situation,

and recognize that you may be
susceptible to a certain degree

of overconfidence in your
beliefs about different events.

And so one thing that can be helpful
is to sort of consult with others,

right, who have their own sort of
experiences and perspectives.

In thinking about what
might happen in the future,

it might be helpful to have
forecasts from many different people,

rather than just rely
on your own information.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

At this stage, most people are
aware of research that shows how

stereotypes impact the way that
we perceive other people, right?

So we think about stereotype as shaping
our sort of impressions of other people

based upon their group membership, right,
maybe their gender or their race.

And really, what my research
has focused on is thinking about

how those same types of stereotypes
shape our beliefs about ourselves.

So in the same way that
I might underestimate
the ability of another woman in math,

that same stereotype would lead me to
underestimate my own ability in math.

And so it's really about sort of
seeing the impact of stereotypes

on the beliefs we
hold about ourselves,

what we're good at,
what we're not so good at.

And those types of
beliefs are so important,

particularly when we think
about workplace outcomes.

Because when you think about decisions
like, should I apply for this job,

should I speak up
with my idea about

what it makes sense to do in
this challenging situation,

should I voice my
opinion on a board, right?

All of those decisions come down
to thinking about, how good am I?

How good is my idea, right?
Is it worth, sort of putting it out there?

And so my research really
shows that those beliefs

tend to be biased by
gender stereotypes,

and that matters for
the ideas and the talent

that gets brought forward in
all sorts of workplace settings.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

One important lesson that
I take from my own research

is that this is less about
sort of men versus women,

and more about the
impact of stereotypes.

And what matters in terms of
outcomes in the studies that I do

is less about, are you a man,
are you a woman?

But instead, are you someone
who's trying to operate

in sort of a gender
congruent domain?

Are you a man in one of those
male stereotypical domains?

Or, are you a woman in one of
those female stereotypical domains, right?

Or, are you trying to operate in
one of those incongruent, right, spaces,

where you're actually a
woman in a male type domain
or a man in a female type domain, right?

And so it adds some
nuance to the picture,

where it's not women do
this and men do that.

It's really about, okay, well, when we're
sort of trying to work against stereotypes,

well we know that those sort of
more negative stereotypes

make us a little bit more
pessimistic about our own abilities,

a little bit less likely
to speak up with our ideas,

a little bit less likely
to apply for a promotion.

But it's the stereotype,
not the fact that I'm a woman,

that seems to be driving
some of those behaviors.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

When I talk about these issues
with exec ed participants,

I overwhelmingly get told one particular
statistic that people have heard, right?

And it's the statistic about when
people apply for a promotion.

Men apply for a promotion when they have
something like 60% of the qualifications,

and women are going to wait until they have
all of them and then a little bit more.

And it's amazing to me how much the
statistic resonates with participants.

And I hear it just as often from women
as I do from men in my audiences,
that it's been out there.

And it's really that
sort of insider anecdote,

is at the root of a lot of the work
that I do in thinking about, okay,

well, how do people sort
of form those beliefs about

when they're ready for a promotion,
when they are good enough?

And in fact, one of my research studies
looks exactly at that type of question.

We actually create these
promotion opportunities,

or advancement opportunities
for participants in the study,

and we look at sort of female
candidates and male candidates,
and the qualifications they have,

and then we track people's
willingness to actually apply for the
promotion opportunity.

And what we see,
sort of consistent with that anecdote,

is that women are less
willing to apply than men,

conditional on having the same
observed qualifications in our study.

But this isn't sort of like a
universal fact, in the sense that

even though women are sort of
less willing to apply on average,

we do see that there are things from sort
of the employer, the recruiter perspective,

that can be done to
change those outcomes.

And in particular,
being a little bit more precise

about what it means to be
qualified for this opportunity,

can help to increase the rate at which
talented women apply for the position.

So it seems to be the case
that ambiguity or uncertainty

about what it means
to be good enough,

sort of creates the space for
some of these biases to show up
and impact outcomes.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Bias training can take different
forms in different organizations,

but a common theme of a lot of bias
training is trying to raise awareness

among employees about
the existence of bias, right?

And so those biases may be related to
race or gender or socioeconomic status,

but sort of making people aware of
the fact that individuals have biases,

and that these biases can impact
some of the behaviors and actions
they take in the workplace.

There are a number of researchers
who have tried to look at

and measure the impacts of
bias training in the workplace,

and I think the general message
coming from a lot of that research

is that bias training may not do as much
as we maybe hope or think it would do.

And so the question is, you know,
what can we do instead, right?
What can we do differently?

Are there things that research shows
us might actually have an impact

on sort of the decisions that
employees take in the workplace, right?

And I think that's really
the missing link

in some of this bias training
that's out there, right?
Not all, but a lot.

If we're just increasing
awareness of bias,

it can be really hard for
employees to know, okay,

now I'm aware that I may have this
bias, but like, what do I do about it?

And I think it's that ‘now what’ that
is really important to take seriously

when we think about sort of
making changes in the workplace

that might actually
impact employee behavior.

What some of the research
of my colleagues has shown
is that bias training in general,

when it's done sort of at a random interval
in time, where maybe you log on online,

and I hear this from my exec
participants all the time, right, they say,

“Oh, those bias trainings.
I go on, I click through.”

I had a participant tell me
they had their teenage daughter
click through for them, right?

So you get all these sort of
stories of the ways in which people

are not really engaged with this
training, because of, I think a sort of

well-founded skepticism of whether
this is actually moving the needle.

And so I think it can be really
helpful to give people sort of

more specific techniques about how they
might actually do things differently,
rather than just increase awareness.

And so some examples of this
includes thinking about how

we actually structure
policies in the organization.

So if I kind of step back and you
thought about a model of employee action, right,

well we might worry that bias is going to sort
of impact the action an employee takes, right?

So maybe it's a hiring decision,
and we might worry that the bias they hold

is going to change the
hiring decision they make.

So one approach, and maybe the classic
bias training approach would be,

okay, we're going to take that
hiring manager and we're going to
make them less biased, right?

We're going to sort of increase their
awareness of the fact they might be biased,
and then they'll make a better decision.

Well, an alternative approach,
or maybe a complimentary approach,

is rather than just try and decrease the
bias that that hiring manager may have,

to actually put in place hiring
processes that make it less likely

that even a biased manager
makes a biased decision.
What do I mean by that?

Well, you could imagine sort
of blinding applications,

so that they don't know what
group the candidate belongs to.

You could imagine introducing
more objective criteria

about how are we
evaluating candidates,

so there's less wiggle room and
ambiguity about what we're looking for.

And so it's those type of like
process changes or policy changes

that can be really powerful
for actually changing outcomes.

Even if we're maybe not
able to change people, right?

And debias people
in the short run,

we can still impact outcomes
by sort of having them operate

through different
policies and procedures.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

I think it's always been true,
and research has shown this as well, right,

that the most successful efforts
in this space are efforts that are

really tightly integrated with the
core mission of an organization.

DEI efforts that are sort of siloed
or seen as some extra activity
housed primarily in an HR function,

that aren't well integrated with
the rest of an organization's goals,
tend to struggle, right?

They tend to struggle, especially if
they don't have buy-in from other leaders

in the organization,
or it's not clear to employees

how they're serving the
organization's primary goals.

And so in this moment
and any other moment,

it's a really important
time to recognize, okay,

how is the work
that we want to do

connected to the organization's
key goals and mission?

And some of the changes that research
has shown can make a difference,

I think you could frame
less as being about sort of

diversity or inclusion for
diversity and inclusion’s sake.

But really,
how do we sort of capitalize

on the best ideas and
talent that's out there?

And so I think with that lens,
and thinking about how to apply that lens

to different processes that
the firm leads and takes on,

whether it's hiring or
performance reviews, promotions;

if we sort of approach
that from an angle of

we want to make sure we're
getting the best ideas and talent, right,

that can be a way
of sort of centering

what is clearly a goal that
everyone would agree makes sense.

You can make that sort of foundational
to a lot of these efforts,

and in that way,
have them more tightly connected

to what the firm's purpose is,
and increase buy-in.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

A lot of researchers have devoted
ample resources to understanding

gender differences
between men and women.

Well, what if we sort of tried to
understand not only those preferences

and beliefs among men and women,
but also among non-binary individuals?

And so that's sort of where
the project is coming from.

It is a sort of large scale survey
where really what we try and do

is ask about a variety of behaviors, across
men, women, and non-binary individuals,

across a sort of diverse
swath of US residents.

We asked them things about sort of their
willingness to initiate negotiations, right,

their self-confidence, their risk
preferences, their social preferences, right?

How they, sort of their
altruism towards others.

We also ask them some of their
experiences at work and at life, right,

whether they've experienced
discrimination in a workplace setting,

in an educational setting,
in sort of the legal setting, right?

We ask about those
types of experiences.

We ask them about
their life aspirations.

And so what we do is we sort of look
across all those different measures

and we just present
descriptive evidence.

Now you could go in, I think,
with a sort of naive model,

and I think many of us have
naive models at this point,

and think, you know,
non-binary individuals, well,

maybe if we thought about sort of a measure
like risk preferences or confidence,

they're going to be
between men and women.

And what our research shows is actually
that doesn't seem to be the case
for a lot of these measures.

So in particular, what we see is that
on measures related to self-confidence
or assertiveness at work,

that in many cases non-binary individuals
are actually less self-confident,

less assertive in some of these ways, 
even compared to women,
and much less so than men.

And so I think it's just
helpful for understanding, right,

to the extent that we think willingness
to compete or self-confidence

matters for workplace outcomes,
and we've thought about that

as being important in understanding
the gap between men and women
in some of these workplace outcomes.

Some of those factors might also be
really relevant for thinking about

sort of disparities across non-binary
individuals, and men and women.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

I think it's important to recognize that,
at least in the data that we collect,

these levels of experience discrimination
among non-binary individuals

are quite high, even relative to
discrimination faced by women,

or sort of the discrimination that we
see against LGB individuals, right?

So levels of experience
discrimination seem to be high,

and I think that's something as
managers we need to be mindful of.

The other thing that
we see in this study

is some evidence in differences in
aspirations among non-binary individuals,
and men and women.

I think it is helpful
to keep in mind, right,

that not everyone is necessarily
motivated by the same things, right?

To the extent that people are
motivated by money or success or power, right,

well, those levers aren't necessarily
going to be equally powerful
for all the employees you manage.

And so understanding what people are
hoping to get out of their career,
what makes them tick, right,

how they feel they would be motivated to
do their best work, is really important, right?

And the sort of model you have
in mind of your typical employee

might not be the model that
makes sense for everyone.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

One of the more fun cases I've worked
on is a case with Progress Software,
which is a global organization.

I think some of the challenges the
challenges the organization has
will resonate with a lot of managers.

So one, operating in all
different places over the world.

So you've got employees of all different
backgrounds working in different places.

And another interesting wrinkle is
they also grow through acquisition.

So at any moment in time, you're
bringing in new cohorts of employees,

that, forget their
geographic background,

are also coming maybe from a
different organizational background

that had different
norms and procedures, right?

So you've got all these
challenges in terms of

bringing people into an
organizational culture,

and helping them get on board with
like, this is how we do things here.

And so the case study thinks about
efforts that Progress Software has made

to try and make it easier for people to
navigate advancement in the organization.

And so retention and talent management,
so critically important for firm leaders, right?

Particularly for a company
like Progress Software,

that's working at least for the
people in their technical roles,
in a highly competitive industry.

And so one of the things they did is they
went back through all of their data

to try and understand, okay,
what does representation look like?

Like, who is advancing
in our organization?

And not just looking at like top level
numbers, but really trying to understand,

like, which offices,
which roles, which functions, right?

To understand, okay, are there pockets of
sort of success we should be looking at,

and pockets of struggle where
we should be targeting efforts?

The other thing they did is they
tried to understand, right, what the state of

sort of talent management and performance
reviews looked like in the moment.

And so one of the things they noticed
is they were asking their managers

to provide sort of feedback to
employees on a semi regular basis

with something called 
a snapshot, right?

So think of a few short questions
that you're supposed to ask

about your direct reports,
and you sort of fill in the buttons
and send it off to headquarters.

It turns out that a lot of those
snapshots weren't happening, right?

And it wasn't necessarily that they
weren't happening at similar rates

across all members of the
organization, because as you'd expect,

some people seem to be more
plugged in than others, right?

So managers seem to be
giving more feedback,

in particular to men than
women, on average.

And so one of the questions
they tried to think about was,

well, how do we sort of increase
the quality and frequency

of this type of performance feedback that
reports are getting from their managers?

And so they introduced a really
interesting intervention that I think

we can sort of take pieces of and sort
of apply in lots of different contexts.

So one thing they did was they really
just tried to normalize the idea
that on a very regular basis,

managers are going to talk to every
single one of their reports about

what the career path looks like and
what the next step towards promotion is, right?
And this is sort of two parts.

So one is thinking about,
what does that employee want, right?

So your impression of
what that employee wants

may not actually be the step they have in
mind for the next step in their career.

And the next is sort of saying, okay,
well, what do you need to get there?
Like, what is the next step?

What's the skill you're missing,
what's the experience you're missing,
and how do we get you there?

And they're really
trying to normalize that.

So you can imagine, I mean,
I could certainly imagine

that it might be really intimidating to
walk into your manager's office and say,

“Hey, I'd really like to talk to you
about how I get promoted.” Right?

And that the people who are willing
to initiate that conversation,

it might not be everyone,
and we might worry in particular

that maybe men are more comfortable
initiating that conversation than women.
And so by normalizing it

and saying this is something
that has to happen every quarter,

you're sort of reducing some of those
norms, right, or stereotypes about like,

what does it mean to assert yourself?
Is it okay?

You're saying, this is okay,
and in fact, we expect you to do it.

The other piece that they put out
there was that they recognized that

there was sort of a lot of uncertainty
and lack of clarity around, like,

what the actual ladders
were in the organization.

And so one of the things they partnered
with this career conversations intervention

was just a really ambitious effort
to do the leveling work of saying,
like, here's the map, right?

Here are all the different sort of paths
of advancement, horizontal, vertical,

here's what we call things,
here's what's comparable, right?

And to not only do that work,
but then also try and make it accessible

and out there for all of
their employees, right?

So increasing awareness of the
existence of this information

in ways that's just
available to everyone.

So it's that sort of like
reduction in ambiguity

that can also be helpful in sort of
reducing the disparities in outcomes.

My experiences, both in the classroom
and in talking to organizations,

suggest that leading with data can be a
really helpful way of navigating this, right?

And I think those sort of data-driven
approaches make it easier

for more people to feel sort of
included in the conversation,

because it doesn't feel as
risky to be able to sort of
ground the conversation in hard data,

than it does in sort of the
open-ended, sort of types of conversations.
I think it's a hard moment, right?

But I think I come back to, 
at least, right, trying to find those sort of

common goals that we have
across the organization, right?

Where if it's really about
the organization's success

and the organization's
productivity, right, that is a shared goal

that we can all have, and in principle,
should not be leaving people behind, right?

So if I'm the leader,
I want to motivate any effort from sort of

that perspective as being really
central to the organization's goal,

and having a really strong
argument about why that's the case, right?

And I think I would sort of be open to the
fact that it's going to require persuasion.

And good persuasion
often requires data.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

When managers think about a
gender gap in the workplace,

maybe a pay gap, or they see men being
promoted at higher rates than women,
a lot of times, and maybe rightly so,

people think about sort of
discrimination and bias, right?

How are sort of the leaders,
the managers, making decisions that

treat men and women differently in ways
that are contributing to those outcomes?

Sometimes what gets lost is actually
that disparities can also have
sort of supply side explanations,

which is, if you thought about
sort of who gets promoted, right,

it's not just about of the candidates
that apply, who gets chosen,
but also who applies.

And sometimes we miss that,
the sort of decisions about who applies,

who chooses to negotiate,
who chooses to voice their idea.

Those types of decisions that come
from the candidates themselves,

the people supplying the
ideas and the talent;

that those decisions also can
contribute to disparities.

I think sometimes we
focus our interventions

on sort of the discrimination side,
and we neglect sort of opportunities

we may have to shape supply
side decisions as well, right?

And so I think that can be an important
set of considerations for managers

to think about,
how do I actually increase the supply
of people who are coming forward, right?

And maybe that's about
choosing better processes.

Maybe it's about
reducing ambiguity.

Maybe it is about reducing sort
of discrimination and backlash

so that people actually want
to come forward and apply.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
